DeregistrationReasonOtherText: sold the facility to MaxYield Cooperative on the effective date listed above.

_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Flow limiters (excess flow valves), breakaway couplers have been installed at the risers and a remove emergency shutoff valve at the storage tank
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Pumps, pump seals, pipes & plumbing, electrical and safety equipment.  The breakaway couplers, pressure relief valves and hoses are also inspected and replaced as necessary.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE AT THE ANDERSONS SUPERIOR FARM CENTER

This facility complies with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1989 requirements with amendments for Anhydrous Ammonia storage. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local regulations. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the Superior Volunteer Fire Department (via a 911 call) and request that it respond to the emergency. Incidental to the notification to the fire department, a call to the Region 3 Emergency Planning District (Dickinson County, Iowa LEPC) will be made.

While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may very well be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have be planned. In reality, the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it has been planned. In that event, what may have been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.

The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize the hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e., Anhydrous Ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or acts of God which might occur on our premises.

The primary emergency coordinator for the Superior, Iowa location is Mark Anderson, Facility Manager. His work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided below. In addition, the following individuals (with associated work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers) are to be contacted in order:

                      Mark Anderson, Location Manager
                               WORK:    (712) 858-4491
                               24-Hour:  (712) 330-7921
                            
                     Tom Evans, Operations
                               WORK:     (712) 858-4491

24-hour:   (712) 330-4539
                               Home:    (712) 362-5333

                     Delmar Baines, Operations
                               WORK:     (712) 858-4491
                               24-hour:   (507)  841-1884 
                            

DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT:

This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant. The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at  this facility is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes. 

The system consists of two(2) storage tanks including valves, liquid pump(s), and other miscellaneous equipment. From time-to-time throughout the year numerous portable nurse tanks may also be present at this site.  The anhydrous ammonia plant is only operated on a seasonal basis (Spring and Fall).  At a maximum, the plant operates a total of three months (1/4 of the year).

WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO:

The worst-case scenario is the failure of the largest storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed (85% of capacity), resulting in the release of the total volume in a gaseous (hazardous ammonia vapor cloud) form. 

ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO:

The alternative release scenario involves the failure of a transfer hose while filling a nurse wagon. 

PREVENTION PROGRAM:

The system is protected from major releases by internal excess flow valves, check valves, relief valves, manual shut-off valves, and emergency shut-off valves. The loadout risers used in filling nurse tanks are protected by breakaway couplers designed to immediately stop the flow of ammonia if the line or a hose breaks. All of the main storage tank valves are locked when not in use.

Since this facility is located in relatively close proximity to the Town of Superior and Christopherson Slough/Swan Lake Wildlife Refuge, consideration has been given to the need for no

tifying all affected persons. 

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable State and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1999 with amendments and State Law. 

In addition the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release of anhydrous ammonia. Finally, The Andersons has extended to the Superior Volunteer Fire Department the opportunity to visit our anhydrous ammonia plant.  Mutual aid departments including the Spirit Lake and Lake Park Fire Departments also attended the facility tour.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

The Andersons Superior Farm Center has never had an accident involving anhydrous ammonia that caused death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia system, it is the policy of The Andersons to immediately notify the Superior Volunteer Fire Department and the Region 3 Emergency Planning District (Dickinson County, Iowa LEPC) to request that they respond to the emergency. In the unlikely event that the Superior Fire Department is unable to adequately respond to an emergency at our Superior location, the Volunteer Fire Department with whom Superior has a reciprocal agreement will be summoned.  We have discussed this policy with the fire department and Region 3 Emergency Planning District (Dickinson County LEPC). Members of the fire department and the LEPC have toured our anhydrous ammonia plant. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

The plan is to minimize hazards to human health and to the environment from spills and accidental releases. A safety inspection is performed before product is moved f

rom the storage tank to nurse tanks. By doing a monthly walk around inspection of the facility a person is able to detect any problems before they arise. If any part of the system showed signs of stress, or if odors are present, corrective measures are taken to repair the system before the facility experiences any problems. Employees are trained so they are aware of the hazards of handling and transferring anhydrous ammonia. All employees handling anhydrous ammonia are required to comply with all safety measures and rules set forth by The Andersons.
